div.p:
96. Of the memorials relating to the duel, all which were referred to the Cilley Committee I moved that the one from the President and professors of Cambridge University should be printed— Mallory of Virginia objected, and moved to lay the Memorial itself on the table. I called for the yeas and nays, upon which Mallory withdrew his objection the Memorial was referred and ordered to be printed— I asked that the Petition from the Revolutionary Soldiers should be read The Clerk began to read, but as soon as he reached the word Slavery three or four Southern members started up and it was
laid on the table— The Petition from P. Force &c for a bounty on mulberry trees was referred to the Committee of Manufactures as were some others— I presented the Petition for expunging the Declaration of Independence from the Journals of the Old Congress, together with a Petition for rescinding the Resolution of 21. Decr. 1837. and moved the reference of them to a select Committee to report thereon.— Campbell of South-Carolina was up, and began a Speech but the Speaker stop’d him, and Cushman moved to lay both Petitions on the table, which was done— I asked if the Committee of foreign Affairs intended to report on the Peace Petitions; but no answer was given— Neither the Chairman of the Committee, nor I believe any member of it was in the house— There was no Quorum in the House three fourths of the day— There were two calls of the House, both suspended as soon as a quorum appeared. Mr Webster was making a great anti-sub-treasury Speech in the Senate— J. Sergeant lent me for the Night, the manuscript of part of his Minority report, on the Treasury Bill from the Committee of Ways and Means.— The House adjourned at 4. O’Clock— Aaron Leggett was here this evening, detailing over again his grievances against the Government of Mexico, and urging absurdly for measures of bullying— Mr Frye was also here— The dam of the Columbian Mills has been carried away by a violent freshet and breaking up of the Ice; and a heavy charge in prospect to rebuild it—
13. VI. Tuesday.

On my way to the Capitol this morning, I stop’d at Fullers and left for A. H. Everett a Letter with an Ode on the battle of Bunker’s Hill, by Francis Durivage, and at the Office of the Secretary of the Treasury, with whom I left the application fromEllis and Jesse Murdock of Carver, for the return of 50 dollars paid at Mobile, as a fine by the Captain of a Schooner belonging to them, for not producing a clearance; David Nye the Surveyor at Wareham, having refused to issue one; upon the allegation that it was not required in the wasting trade— I received in the course of the morning a Letter of notification that the case had been referred for a report to the Collector at Mobile—
H.R.US. I returned to Mr Sergeant his unfinished Manuscript report— John Reed came to my Seat, and proposed a meeting of the Massachusetts delegation at ten O’Clock to-morrow Morning to which I assented, to consult together again, upon the answer to be given to Mr Alvord the Chairman of the joint Committee of the Massachusetts Legislature— The fear of responsibility in this case, is a two-edged sword— I told Mr Reed again what I have constantly repeated—that I would answer the Letter in any way upon which they would agree— The House was deserted again this day— Mr Webster finished his Speech in the Senate; universally thought the most splendid and powerful of his efforts—there was no possibility of keeping a quorum in the House— Mr. W. Cost Johnson continued another quarter of an hour his Speech, upon his resolution concerning the public Lands, and Schools, where the hour expired, and the order of the day, the civil and diplomatic appropriation Bill was resumed in Committee of the Whole, Z. Casey is the Chair— Rariden of Indiana toiled much to get inserted an increase of the contingencies of the House, to pay for the books, purchased for the new members of the House; but Cambreleng threw so many obstructions in his way that he was obliged to give it up— Howard moved an additional item of outfit, for a Chargé d’Affaires to Peru—which Petriken opposed, because of the bad effect of these multiplied diplomacies upon the democratic party— M’Kim was for the appropriation, and repeated at least ten times that he would be willing to contribute from his own pocket, his share to make up for a full Minister to Peru— Matthias Morris moved to reduce the item of contingencies for the foreign Missions from 30 to 20,000 dollars, but without success.— About 4 O’Clock the Committee rose and the House adjourned— Mary and Elizabeth Isaac Hull and John Quincy spent the Evening at Mr Frye’s— I attended Mr Buckingham’s 3d. Lecture on Egypt— Alexandria, and Canopus—Population—two Millions?— Library, 200000 volumes Pompey’s Pillar 11 1/2 feet diameter 90 feet long, Sienite granite Cleopatra’s Needle— 16. Pillars of the Temple of Serapis—
14. VI— Wednesday—

I called on Mr Freeman the miniature Painter to whom I had promised to sit this morning, and informed him that I was obliged to go immediately to the Capitol— There in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures I met with the members of the Massachusetts delegation, to consult together again, about the answer to Mr Alvord, Chairman of the joint Committee of the Massachusetts Legislature— Present Adams, Borden, Briggs, Hastings, Lincoln, Phillips, and Reed, who had requested the Meeting— Absent Calhoun, Fletcher, Cushing Grennell and Parmenter— The Committee of two, Fletcher and Reed, appointed at the last meeting to prepare an answer in place of my draft had not been more fortunate than myself, in suiting the views of a majority of the delegation, and now after much discussion at Reed’s motion Briggs and Hastings were chosen a committee to prepare an answer as short and irresponsible as possible— The difficulty all along has been Lincoln’s terror of responsibility; and he still declines taking any part in the preparation of the answer— H.R.U.S— Fairfield had sundry Petitions relating to the Cilley duel which he asked leave to present—objection was made, and he asked a suspension of the rules, and the yeas and nays—but withdrew the last motion— After taking twice the question without the yeas and nays, and no quorum, they were again called, and gave a vote of 90 to 54. not two thirds, and Fairfield could not present his Petitions—among the negative votes were no small proportion of his own party— The business of the day was miscellaneous. W. Cost Johnson continued for half an hour, his Speech, on the public Lands and Schools— He touched on nullification, and was called to order by the Speaker, who since Calhoun’s chop round to the Northern man with Southern principles, has become tenderly observant of the feelings of nullifiers. A Bill was received from the Senate authorising two Citizens of Georgia, to import free of duty, two iron Steamboats— I moved its reference to the Committee of Manufactures— Dawson of Georgia proposed the Committee of Commerce, and James Graham the Committee of Ways and Means— I discussed the question with Dawson and Holsey, and the bill was
referred to the Committee of Manufactures The civil and diplomatic appropriation bill came up, and M’Kay moved to strike out the item of 4000 dollars for the Consuls at London and Paris; which as I took part in the discussion made a sharp debate, and the Committee rose without taking the question and the House adjourned— Evening at Mrs Madison’s.
15. VI:30. Thursday

Mr. Heman Lincoln of Boston paid me a morning visit—recently married at Philadelphia— Mrs Madison had requested that I would call to see her and I went last evening— Her object was to consult me respecting the publication of her late husband’s manuscripts, and she said she had concluded to have one volume of correspondence concerning Constitutional Questions since 1829 published immediately by the Harper’s at New-York. I attended this morning a Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures—present Adams, Biddle, Slade, Tillinghast, Vail and Webster. Absent Foster, Hunter and Naylor— Mr Force, Hall, Michael Nourse, and Lindsley were there, and explained their wishes to the Committee, upon the two memorials for the encouragement of the growth and manufacture of silk in this district— The Committee met again after the adjournment of the House— H.R.U.S. George Evans announced the death of his Colleague Timothy James Carter last evening at ten O’Clock—and pronounced the most eloquent and pathetic eulogy upon him that I ever heard delivered on a similar occasion— He then moved the usual resolution of crape mourning, and attendance at the funeral, and the adjournment over to Saturday at Noon, for which time the funeral has been fixed— At the second meeting of the Committee the questions concerning the silk memorials were resumed; and considered and without coming to any conclusion postponed— The bill to allow the importation of two iron steamboats free of duty, was taken up, and the memorials upon which the bill was founded were read—together with others which Mr Haynes of Georgia had procured to be transferred from the Committee of Ways and Means to the Committee of Manufactures— I found to my no small surprize that Mr Biddle, from Pittsburg was in favor of the Bill— His
predecessor Harmar Denny, had been in the last Congress, the most inflexible adversary to the same Bill— I therefore said to the Committee that relying upon Mr Biddle’s guardian care of the iron manufacturing interest, I saw no reason why we should not report the Bill to the House without amendment and recommend its passage— It was however agreed to postpone it for further consideration.— At near 3. O’Clock the Committee adjourned— On my way home I called at the Intelligencer Office, and took a paper of the 14th of February, to replace one which Mrs Adams sent to Sarah M. Grimke— I spoke to Mr Seaton, recommending to him to take minutes of documents for a supplementary Volume to their great collection— Instancing Genet’s instructions, and Yrujo’s protest and remonstrance against Mr Jefferson’s Message in January 1806. and also Mr Madison’s Examination of the British doctrine of Neutral trade in time of War— In the Evening, Mr Smith called, and with my wife I attended Mr Buckingham’s 4th. Lecture which was upon Memphis and the Pyramids—very amusing.
16. VII. Friday

At 11 this morning I called on Mr Freeman, and found he had packed up his trunks, to start at 4 this afternoon for Baltimore and Philadelphia. He said he had expected to go this morning, and had written me a note to give me notice of this, but, had afterwards postponed his departure till this afternoon, and therefore had not sent his note to me— He unpacked his trunks and took a sitting of more than three hours, which entirely exhausted my patience— Yet he did not finish, but bespoke other sitting, after his return from Philadelphia, which he expects will be in the course of a week or ten days— On my way homeward I stopped to visit Mr Fendall, who on the 18th. of January in the Evening by a false step in the dark, fell over a precipitous descent of about fourteen feet and broke his leg in three places.— He said it was only the day before yesterday that he had been able to come down from his bed-chamber, and he is yet unable to stand; but appears to bear his fortune with composure—
I dined with President Van Buren, with my two nephews Isaac Hull, and Midshipman John Quincy Adams—the other company, were Mr Forsyth Secretary of State—Mr Poinsett, Secretary of War, Cambreleng, De Graeff and Kemble, members of the House of Representatives from New-York, Alexander H. Everett, three young men, named Hamilton, Hoit and Young, Martini, the Chargé d’Affaires from Holland and Mr Van Buren’s three Sons; Abraham, Martin and John— I had some conversation with him upon the affairs of Canada, and some upon the condition of the Banks in Boston, Mr Woodbury, the Secretary of the Treasury came in after dinner and another person, a Stranger. Mr Kemble brought us home for it rained— I lost Mr Buckingham’s fifth Lectures upon the City of Thebes, in Egypt.— But Mrs Adams went with Mr W. S. Smith, and heard it.
17. V. Saturday

Rainy Night and stormy day— The Midshipman rode with me to the Capitol in the midst of the storm— The House met at noon, andKeim, a new member from Pennsylvania, chosen to supply the place of Henry A Muhlenberg was sworn in by the Speaker— There is nothing favourably prepossessing in his first appearance— The funeral services for Timothy Jarvis Carter the member from Maine were jointly performed by Mr Hawley, who performed the episcopal church service for the burial of the dead, and by Mr Reese the Chaplain of the Senate, who delivered a short discourse from Matthew 24:44 [“]Therefore be ye also ready: for in such an hour as ye think not the Son of man cometh.” Mr Reese made perhaps as much of his subject, as was to be drawn from it— The President and Secretaries of State and the Treasury were there—ten or twelve Senators, and perhaps fifty members of the House— Mr Slicer the Chaplain was not there— Mr Hawley read even the parts of the service which are usually recited at the grave.— I did not go in the procession to the burying yard; but rode home, my namesake having left me, and walked home— The storm continued through the day, and Evening finally turned to Snow—
18. V:30. Sunday.

A second stormy night, and this morning the ground was covered with Snow— The gale continued through the day with successive snow, sleet and rain, subsiding towards night.— I attended the morning service at St. John’s Church— Mr Hawley read prayers for the 3d. Sunday in Lent, and preached a very short discourse from Isaiah 55.12. [“]For ye shall go out with joy, and be led forth with Peace: the mountains and the hills shall break forth before you into singing, and all the trees of the field shall clap their hands. 13. Instead of the thorn shall come up the fir tree, and instead of the brier shall come up the myrtle tree; and it shall be to the Lord for a name, for an everlasting sign that shall not be cut off.”— The auditory was very small, and Mr Hawley gave notice that owing to the condition of the Streets there would be no service at the Church this afternoon— I was occupied the remainder of the day in writing to my Son, and in assorting my papers— I was desirous of taking up the pamphlet published last Spring, issued anonymously from the Department of State, under the title of examination and review of a pamphlet, printed and secretly circulated by M. E. Gorostiza late Envoy Extraordinary, from Mexico; previous to his departure from the United States, and by him entitled correspondence between the Legation extraordinary of Mexico and the Department of State of the United States respecting the passage of the Sabine by the Troops under the command of General Gaines— I have lent my copy of it to Mr Menefee; and wanting it now, have borrowed one from Mr Seaton— The scribe of the Department of State begins a controversy with Gorostiza upon the claim of France to Texas, by quoting for his authority the third volume of Hennepin’s book which is known to be an imposture— It is a fearful forethought to me, to have to hunt up all these testimonies again after having consumed so much time as I did in it before— And distracted as I am with a multitude of other objects calling for attention, while the mere assortment of papers and filing of Letters received leaves me not even time to keep my daily diary.
19. VI:30. Monday

H.R.U.S— The Speaker after presenting to the House sundry communications from the Departments, called the States for Resolutions, beginning with Maine— I offered a Resolution, requiring that the Clerk of the House should make out a list of the Petitions, Memorials, Remonstrances and Resolutions presented at the special, and at the present Session of Congress, which have been laid on the table, without being read, printed, debated, or referred— Cushman of New-Hampshire the mover general to lay all such papers on the table, objected to this Resolution, and the Speaker laid it over as causing debate— The number of Resolutions offered was about 80.— J. M. Patton moved a suspension of the rules, to take up his Resolutions about patronage and removals from Office, and make them the special order of some future day— He called for the yeas and nays, and just obtained them 71 to 66.—105 members absent— The Call for Resolutions was succeeded by a call for Petitions, of which I presented fifteen, and the Speaker went through all the States with both Calls; and the House adjourned between 3 and 4. O’Clock. Immediately after dinner—at 7. I went with my wife and Mr Smith to Mr Buckingham’s 6th. and last Lecture upon Egypt.— He gave notice of a new course of 3. Lectures upon Palestine, to be given on Thursday, Friday and Saturday Evenings next.— Mrs Stewart and Mrs Parnell rode home with Mrs Adams and they left me at the door of Mr Pontois the French Minister, who had an Evening party and supper— Parties of a description which I have almost entirely ceased to attend— Miss Kemble, sister of Mr Gouverneur Kemble, and Madame Tacon late Miss Hughes played on the Piano and sung, not amiss, but Madame Caradori-Allan the professional singer was there, and refused to sing though requested by Mrs Webster and by me, who at the solicitation of Mr Pontois, asked her to sing—but who thought her right in refusing— Mr Legare, asked me some questions about the claim of Mrs Meade, upon which he is to report— Conversation with Mr Clay— Also with Mr Forsyth and Mr Fox— Home at one in the morning—
20. VII. Tuesday.

There was notice in the Newspapers of this day, that Mr Buckingham will deliver four Lectures on Palestine, in Dr Laurie’s Church on the Evenings of tomorrow, Thursday, Friday and Saturday.— At the House, upon the call on the Committees for reports, a multitude of private Bills were reported— William Cost Johnson continued his Speech on the disposal of the public Lands, till the expiration of the morning hour— The civil and diplomatic appropriation Bill was considered in Committee of the whole on the Union Casey in the Chair— Cambreleng offered an amendment increasing from 30 to 40000 dollars the item for the relief and protection of American Seamen— I enquired the reason for this increase— Cambreleng had nothing but a Letter from the Secretary of State saying that it would be necessary— A. H. Sheppard and M’Kay made a debate upon it, which I encouraged, to ascertain the cause of the increased appropriation, which proves to be the loss on exchange in making remittances, and alteration in the mode of making remittances, which instead of being made to the Bankers in London, with power to the Consuls to draw upon them under the supervision of the Minister, are now (since 1835) all made by Bills of the Consuls drawn directly upon the Department of State and therefore subject to enormous losses of exchange— Howard assisted Cambreleng in supporting the increase of appropriation—as did M’Kim and Phillips, as merchants— I did not oppose it, my object being only to ascertain its cause— Shepperd and M’Kay would have cut it down— A question was taken and the vote on the amendment was 44 to 19. no Quorum— The Committee rose and reported the fact to the House— Reed moved to adjourn and called for the yeas and nays to make a quorum 121 to 9.— Bell made one of his foolish motions to amend the Bill by a Section to reduce 25 per cent the Salaries of all executive Officers, appropriated for in the Bill— All such motions are waste of time, and inherently unjust, but they make warm debate as did this— Casey pronounced Bell’s amendment not in order, from which Bell appealed— The decision of the Chairman was sustained 66 to 57— Halstead moved to
strike out a paltry item of appropriation of 4000 dollars, for a jet d’eau in the Capitol Yard and gave note of a formidable speech against that and other items, and against the whole bill— So the Committee rose, and the House adjourned at 4.— In the Evening I went with my wife, and Mary, and Elizabeth, and my two nephews Isaac Hull and John Quincy Adams to Madame Caradori-Allan’s concert at Carusi’s Saloon— She sung an Italian air, una voce poco fa—Handel’s Angels ever bright and fair—A German song Steh nur auf—and two light Scottish songs, in which last she accompanied herself on the Piano.— In the intervals A Signor Fabj sung Italian airs—indifferently— The hall was more crowded than I had ever seen it.— I was pleased with the singing, but felt much like Barzillai in the time of David.— The performances were all short— Home between 10 and 11.
21. VII. Wednesday.—

Equinoctial day— The first two of these names are Philadelphia Quakers— The other two Seneca Indians, coming with fruitless complaints against one of Schermerhorn’s swindling Treaties— They had a long address to me, which I advised them to take first to the Massachusetts Senators Webster and Davis— These applications of Indians to me, to befriend them distress me, knowing how much they are wronged, and my utter inability to obtain for them either Justice, or relief— H.R.U.S.— W. Cost Johnson being indisposed, his Resolution was postponed until to morrow— H. Everett’s call, for information of our relations with Mexico was adopted— Cushman moved to go into Comee. of the whole on a Bill from the Senate, about the explosion of Steam-boilers; and moved the suspension of the rules— I insisted that the hour should be wholly devoted to the consideration of Resolutions, and Cushman’s motion failed— Seven Resolutions which had been on the Calendar, from the 28th. of Decr to the 19th. of Decr. to the 19th. of Feby were now disposed of, and one withdrawn— Clark of New-York moved to fix a day for the consideration of the sub-treasury Bill reported by the Comee. of
Ways and Means, but failed— Fillmore’s call on P.U.S. for documents relating to the capture and destruction of the Steam-boat Caroline, was earnestly resisted by M’Kim, but finally carried— Three Letters of the correspondence are in the National Intelligencer this morning; from a communication of Sir Francis B. Head to the Legislature of upper Canada— The Civil list Bill was taken up again in committee of the whole on the Union, Casey in the Chair, and Holsey made his motion to strike out the item of 4000 dollars for a jet d’eau in the Capitol Yard; giving notice that he should follow it up, by motions to strike out other items of appropriation for the public buildings—and he made this as his text for a general attack upon this administration as wasteful and extravagant— Halstead is a New-Jersey whig, of some eloquence, puny judgment, and egregious vanity— He had prepared a speech of two hours, to be published in the Newspapers, upon a question of 4000 dollars, for a jet d’eau, and on this basis he took a comparative view of all the expenditures of the late administration, compared with mine— Assuming the false and base representations of the retrenchment Committees, as if they were all true and well founded, he presented comparative statements of present expenditures, to double and treble the amount of those then so denounced and reproached— This comparison is addressed to the narrow comprehension, and sordid niggardliness of the ignorant and envious— But Halstead had prepared his battery without considering upon whom it would bear. He was raking fore and aft, the main deck of his own ship— The expenditures for the public buildings were all proposed by the Committee of which Governor Lincoln is chairman, and Mercer, and Legare are members— Bynum first answered him with bitter and most insulting personalities— Lincoln followed and scored him without mercy. Bell of Tennessee, came to the rescue for him, by adverting to the general duty of scrutinizing the public expenditures, and exercising the freedom of debate— Halstead rose to reply but it was 5 O’Clock, the Committee rose and the house adjourned—
Evening with my wife, Mary, Elizabeth, and the two children, I attended Dr Laurie’s Church, Mr Buckingham’s first Lecture on Palestine— The Geographical divisions of the Country—Galilee—Samoria, and Judea— The attendance thin—

22. VI:30. Thursday.— Overton Carr the door keeper of the House of Representatives, died last Monday Night— He had attended in the House last Saturday, but has been many moths in decline. Mercer offered a Resolution that the House would adjourn at 4. O’Clock to attend his funeral, and that his compensation as door-keeper should be paid to his widow till the end of the present Session of Congress, which passed without opposition— Petitions on the subject of the Cilley duel, were presented, by Fairfield, Evans, and Davee of Maine, Williams of New-Hampshire, Paynter, Henry and Davis of Pennsylvania, and Morris of Ohio. Not one from a Slave holding State— W. Cost Johnson closed his Speech upon the public Lands and Schools, and Lawler of Alabama took the floor to answer him, but postponed his speech for the orders of the day— The Civil list Bill in Committee of the whole on the Union. Halstead replied, apologetically to Governor Lincoln, complaining of the harshness of Lincoln’s animadversions upon him—wholly unexpected he said, from that quarter.— Halstead took no notice of Bynum’s violent attack upon him yesterday, and Boon of Indiana gave him this day the Jackass’s kick; which he received without return— Lincoln replied with great moderation, and something of a compunctious visiting for his severity yesterday. Halstead had alluded yesterday to R. M. Johnson the Vice-President’s swarthy wife and dingy children, in a manner which he thought witty, but which provoked Bynum and Boon beyond all measure; and they Savage like, took their revenge.— Mercer with much address moved an amendment to Halstead’s proposed amendment so as to strike out the 4000 dollars for the jet d’eau, but to leave it under a more general appropriation for improving
the grounds according to the plan adopted by the last Congress.— This was rejecting Halstead’s amendment by seeming to adopt it.— Mallory read a Letter from Captain Dallas of the Navy, with an explanation relating to some charge, which Mallory had made in his place against Dallas, and calling upon him to retract it— Mallory said the explanation was not satisfactory, and that he could not retract the charge— Bell renewed his motion to reduce the Salaries of Executive Officers 25 per Cent— Cushman raised upon it the point of Order—the Chairman decided it was not in order— Bell appealed, and the decision of the chair was sustained— Bell then moved to reduce 25 per Cent the appropriations for the pay and mileage of the members, and for the Officers of the House—rejected— The Committee rose and reported the Bill with amendments, and at 4 O’Clock the Speaker declared the House adjourned— I went over to Mr Carr’s house, and heard the episcopal funeral service performed over his remains, by a Clergyman whom I did not know— Part of it was omitted which he said would be performed at the grave. The Speaker, Polk, Lewis Williams and C. F. Mercer were the only members of the house whom I saw there— The other attendance was numerous— Thence I came home; and in the Evening we attended at Dr Laurie’s Church Mr Buckingham’s second Lecture on Palestine— J. Q. Adams the Midshipman taking the place of the two children
23. VII. Friday.

At the request of Mr William S. Hastings, I had attended yesterday in the Committee room of the Committee of elections a meeting of several members of the Massachusetts delegation; to consider Hastings’s draft of an answer to the Letter of Jams C. Alvord Chairman of the joint Committee of the Massachusetts Legislature— Briggs, Borden and Parmenter have all gone home— Calhoun, Cushing, Fletcher and Phillips attended the Meeting yesterday— Also Hastings and Reed— Grennell and Lincoln were absent.— Mr Hastings read his draft, which was discussed, but I was obliged to leave them to attend a meeting of the Committee of Manufactures.— They however formed no Quorum.
Mr Hastings yesterday asked me to attend another meeting of the delegation this morning— I came accordingly; but found no other member at the Committee room— Mr Hastings apologised to me for this Non-attendance and repeated the invitation, for to-morrow Morning— H.R.U S. I presented ten petitions relating to the duel, which were all without reading referred to the special Committee— Petitions of the same kind were presented by several other members, and in like manner referred— M’Kennan moved a Resolution to choose a door keeper next Monday— Some debate, and the subject postponed till next Monday week— Hiland Hall read an Article in the Globe of this morning, charging him and me and 91. members of the House with having voted in 1835 for a Bank divorce— He recurred to the minutes of the Journal, and a Letter from Burch, to prove that he had not so voted.— There was an omission in the Journal itself to shew that there had been a division of the question, and that he had voted only for the recommitment; without the instructions.— Cambreleng, chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, reported a Bill to authorise the issuing of ten Millions more of Treasury Notes— J. Sergeant presented the minority Report from the Committee of Ways and Means, signed by himself and J. Pope; and 10,000 extra copies of both Reports were ordered to be printed— Lawler of Alabama spoke about half an hour against W. Cost Johnson’s Resolution respecting the Public Lands and Schools.— The orders of the day brought up the civil list Bill, and sharp debates, first on the increase from 30 to 40000 dollars of the appropriation for the relief of distressed Seamen, proved to be occasioned by the new system of authorising all the consuls to draw for all their expenditures directly upon the Department, and secondly on a motion by Cambreleng to amend the Bill, by striking out the specifications in the Appropriations for the service of the Post-Office Department, which after no small debate he had himself introduced by amendment into the Bill, while in Committee of the whole— He produced an insolent Letter from the Postmaster General scouting at the idea of
specific appropriations, as containing the reasons for his proposed amendment, which was also supported by Montgomery the present Chairman, and by Connor the late Chairman of the Post-Office Committee— Whittlesey of Ohio, Rice Garland, and A. H. Shepperd insisted upon the specifications— I called for the yeas and nays and Cambreleng’s amendment was rejected 66 to 64— Other amendments were proposed and the House finally adjourned without taking the question on the Bill— There has been all this week scarcely an hour with more than a bare Quorum in the House— The Senate this day passed the Independent Treasury Bill, so now called, by a vote of 27. to 25.— Mr Thomas B. Johnson arrived this day, on his return from Europe where he has spent nearly the last two years— We attended this Evening Mr Buckingham’s third Lecture on Palestine.
24. VI. Saturday.

I attended again in the chamber of the Committee of Elections a meeting of the members of the Massachusetts delegation— Mr Hastings’s draft was further revised and made acceptable to the members from the Commonwealth now here, and was signed by me, and I believe my Colleagues, though by Governor Lincoln with some reservation— H.R.U.S. Patton from the joint Committee on the library reported a Bill to provide for the employment of an agent to the Committee. He reported also a Resolution authorising the Clerk of the House to subscribe for ten copies of Niles’s Register to be delivered to each member of the House, on condition that he shall publish the journals of the House, with the yeas and nays, and the Laws— Consideration postponed till next Tuesday.— Cambreleng moved a suspension of the rules to take up the Civil list Bill which was carried; and the debate and decision, upon the specification of the items in the appropriation for the service of the Post-Office occurred this day and not yesterday, when the Motion to amend was made, but not debated— The debate has disclosed the artfulness with which the Bill now organizing the General Post-Office, was drawn up, to evade the specification of any items of appropriation, and to leave the whole sum appropriated for the service of the general
Post-Office, entirely at the discretion of the Postmaster General— The design was not apparent, on the face of the Bill— It was disguised under a provision, requiring of him specific estimates—and now in his report he says his object has been to substitute specific accountability instead of specific appropriations— The appropriation of the last year in the hurry of the business at the close of the Session passed without specification, by inadvertence, and Cambreleng and Connor and Montgomery now made their strongest argument from the precedent.— Robertson moved to strike out the item of 40000 dollars under the head of miscellaneous, but failed— A Resolution moved by Bell was adopted; calling on the Secretary of the Treasury, for returns of the Treasury Notes, issued and received in payment, and all other revenues received in the last quarter of 1837. and the first of 1838— In the evening we attended the fourth and last Lecture of Mr Buckingham upon Palestine; after which he took leave of me, and is to go to Baltimore on Monday— These Lectures have been very entertaining and instructive—but my attendance on them has absorbed much time; kept me up late at Night, and run my diary and correspondence into arrears—
25. VI:30. Sunday.

I walked to the Capitol, and heard the Revd. Dr Wilbur Fiske, President of the Wesleyan Methodist College, at Middletown, Connecticut, preach from Psalm 97.1. “The Lord reigneth, let the earth rejoice: let the multitude of isles be glad thereof.” It was a temperate well composed discourse, shewing the various reasons, for universal rejoicing at the Government of divine Providence.— I had seen Dr Fiske at the Literary meeting at New-York in October 1831. and not before or since— John Quincy went with me, but the Hall was so crowded that I lost him— In returning I stopp’d at Gadsby’s, and left a Card for Lord Gosford, whom Genl. Macomb had introduced to me in the Hall of the House, without the bar, on Friday— He had brought me a Letter of recommendation from Governor Everett; and cards had
been exchanged between us before— I called also upon Mr Alexander H. Everett at Fuller’s; and he came home with me, and dined with us.— Mrs Frye, her son Thomas, and Mrs Johnston, dined here also— After dinner, I had visits from Mr Childs of New-York, and my old friend Albert H. Tracy whom I had not seen, for ten or twelve years.— The day was thus absorbed, leaving me no time to write.

26. VII. Monday— Petition day— I presented 21— 1. fromfor an increase of his Pension—referred to the Committee of Revolutionary Pensions— 2. for Peace with Mexico—National Arbitration, and a Congress of Nations— One of these was from Thomas Thompson jr and 135 members of the Massachusetts Legislature, which at my motion was ordered to be printed with the names.— Howard made some objection to it, but did not insist— The other was from 535 persons in Maine— I enquired again whether the Committee of foreign Affairs, to which these Petitions were referred, might be expected to report upon the former Petitions of the same import which have already been for months before them.— Howard answered that the Petitions had been referred to a member of the Committee to prepare a report upon them, which had not yet been presented. 3 Petitions relating to the Duel—referred to the select Committee on that subject— 7. to rescind the Resolution of 21. Decr. 1837. 1 against the admission of Texas— 4 for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia 1. in the Territories 1. against the admission of any new Slave State— And 1. praying that all abolition petitions may be laid on the table—and they were all laid on the table— Many Petitions were presented against the practice of duelling; some for the expulsion of all concerned in it—and some for the expulsion of Wise and Graves— Slade presented a great multitude of abolition on petitions— The call for Petitions was gone through in two hours—after which sundry Resolutions were offered—a number of Bills were reported— The Civil list Bill was taken up and Rariden moved his amendment to increase the appropriation for contingent expenses of the house, from 225000 dollars to 273960 to pay for the books voted to the new members of the present
Congress.— The sum is certainly considerable Cambreleng objected to the amendment, as not in order— The Speaker decided it was in order— Cambreleng appealed from his decision and argued the question for some time; but finally withdrew the appeal at the request of Howard. Cushman moved at last and carried the previous question, and Rariden moved a call of the House which was refused, and his amendment was rejected by yeas and nays 71 to 96.— Reed and Ingham attempted to introduce appropriations for light-houses, but failed.— Garland of Louisiana moved a recommit the bill to strike out some extra clerk hire but Connor moved and carried the Previous Question 69 to 57.—only 126 members voting; and the bill passed to be engrossed for the 3d. reading—and the House adjourned— Mr Frye was here this Evening, and spoke of a proposal made to him by some one, to take upon a lease for four years the house, which I gave to my wife and to spend from 350 to 400 dollars upon it in repairs; which Mrs Adams and myself approved— The Independent Treasury Bill as it is now called, or. the sub-treasury Bill, or the divorce Bill, between Bank, and State, passed in the Senate this day by a vote of 27 to 25. after having been strip’d on Saturday of the 23d. Section, which was Calhoun’s device for the gradual approach to the exclusive use of gold and silver, for the receipt and expenditure of the revenue. After breaking off all his whig associations of the banded league against Jackson, for this ignis fatuus, it is extinguished before his eyes, and he voted against the Bill— Mr Johnson dined and spent the day at Mrs W. S. Smith’s. There was a curious document of the Senate; laid on the tables of the members— A report from the Secretary of the Treasury, and from the Postmaster general with an angry, and vituperative correspondence between him and George Thomas the Cashier of the Bank of the Metropolis. It is the most respectful and courteous correspondence in form and the roughest in substance that I ever saw.— The reciprocated charges of fraud and knavery are multitudinous, and amply supported, on both sides. [symbols]
27. V:30. Tuesday.

Mrs Way, who said she was the widow of the brother of Andrew Way, came here this morning in forma pauperis, but comfortable in appearance— At the House—the Resolution reported by Mr Patton from the Library Committee for a subscription to Niles’s Register of ten copies for each member of the House was after some debate, laid on the table by yeas and nays 86 to 79— Sherrod Williams afterwards moved a reconsideration, and Boon moved to lay that motion on the table; which was carried 88 to 84— The independent Treasury Bill was read twice, and Cambreleng moved its reference to the Committee of Ways and Means— Pickens calls upon him to say whether the Soprano from the Senate, was to be considered at all, in preference to the Bill reported to the House— Cambreleng said he and all his colleagues infinitely preferred their own Bill. Sergeant said stop—not so fast.— He had no such infinite preference— He did not know which was the worst of the two— Cambreleng said he of course did not mean those opposed to both Bills— Patton made a speech and moved to lay the Senate Bill on the Table— Glascock implored leave to answer him and he gave it— Glascock complained bitterly of Patton’s unfairness in making this motion when so many true blues were absent— Duncan’s tongue itched to be let loose, but Patton insisted on his motion, which Glascock as pledged, had renewed.— There was a call of the house soon superseded; and the Bill was laid on the table; by a vote of 106 to 97— Hiram Gray voting in the affirmative, and immediately giving notice that he should move for a reconsideration of the vote— The army appropriation Bill was debated in Committee of the whole, Dromgoole in the Chair— No question taken upon it.— The House adjourned at 5— Bell had moved a reduction of the appropriation, for the National armouries, which after some debate he withdrew— J. J. Greenough was here this Evening to take leave of his Cousin, John Quincy, and Elizabeth C Adams who are to depart to morrow Morning— Elizabeth returns to her mother who is now unwell at Medford; and John Quincy goes to visit her— He has a furlough, till the 10th. of next Month. Greenough is employed in the Patent Office—
28. V. Wednesday

At 6 O’Clock this morning Midshipman John Quincy, and his Sister Elizabeth C. Adams left us, to go to their mother— Wilson with his Carriage took them to the Cars. H.R.U.S.— I presented four Petitions relating to the recent duel, which were immediately referred to the select Committee— Cushing, Fairfield, Russell, Grant and Beatty presented similar Petitions, which were referred in the same manner— Whittlesey of Ohio reported from the Committee of claims a Bill to establish a board of Commissioners, to examine and decide certain claims against the United States, which after a few remarks by him was at his motion made the special order of the day for next Friday week— Bell, Chairman of the Committee of Indian Affairs moved that the Committee should be discharged from the further consideration of a memorial from Riverhead, in the State of New-York for an enquiry into the validity of the fraudulent Schermerhorn Cherokee Treaty and that it lie on the table— Everett asked a division of the question— Haynes moved the previous question, and refused to withdraw it, though requested by his Colleague Dawson—but the House would not sustain him— There was a short debate and the question was divided— The Committee was discharged from the further consideration of the Memorial by Yeas and Nays 102. to 75 and it was then laid on the table without division— Bell, Chairman of the Committee voted against his own motion, but it is vain to plead for Justice, in any case concerning Indians.— Army Appropriation Bill taken up in Committee of the whole upon the state of the Union Dromgoole in the Chair— There was a long and desultory debate upon the item of Appropriation for Arsenals, in which Yell of Arkansas made as usual much noise, and said there would be within two years a general Indian War— Bell moved a transfer of an item of more than half a Million from the Bill for the suppression of Indian hostilities; but Cambreleng and Downing the Delegate from the Territory told him it must be if at all two Millions instead of half a Million— Committee rose without reporting the Bill— I met Alexander H. Everett, and Albert H. Tracy, on the floor of the House without the Bar. Everett gave me to read, a Letter from G. Bancroft, the new Collector at Boston—to make a sub-treasury man of me—
29. VI. Thursday.

Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures—Adams, Biddle, Slade, Tillinghast, Vail, Webster. Absent Foster, Hunter, Naylor— I was instructed to report the Iron, Steam boat Bill from the Senate, without amendment— Each member of the Committee reserving to himself the right either to support or oppose its passage, at his discretion. H.R.U.S— I presented a petition relating to the duel, and sundry others were presented by other members; and all, referred to the Committee—Yell, presented a Memorial from the Legislature of Arkansas, respecting the boundary between that State and Mexico—referred to the Committee of foreign Affairs— Howard, from that Committee moved that the Bill to indemnify for French Spoliations prior to 1800 should be made the special order of the day for Friday and Saturday 13. and 14. April— The motion failed by yeas and nays 79 to 63 not two thirds— Lincoln from the Committee on the public buildings reported a Bill to take down the walls now erecting for a Treasury-building, and using them for a fire proof Post Office-building—and moved a special order of the day next Tuesday for considering it—but objection being made, he moved its reference to the Committee of the whole on the Union, which was agreed to— I reported from the Committee of manufactures the Senate’s Iron Steamboat Bill, without amendment. A Resolution offered by Slade, calling for information respecting pre-emption Sales of Lands had been adopted, and Hopkins at the instigation of Lawler had moved its reconsideration— This was now refused.— The army appropriation Bill passed through the Committee of the whole, Dromgoole in the Chair— And the Navy Appropriation—the Exploring Expedition and the Cumberland road Bills were debated and reported to the House— M’Kay was for reducing the number of Midshipmen— Mallory and Montgomery, waged war upon the exploring expedition; and Mallory upon the Secretary of the Navy, who he said was too ridiculous in the opinion of the Nation to deserve his notice.— Wise gave notice that when this bill should come up next Monday, he would move that the exploring expedition should be changed, into a squadron for surveying our own coast— M’Kennan moved amendments to the Cumberland road-Bill, one of which an appropriation for guard fences was adopted— There was a Ball this Evening at Mr Poinsett’s; though he was ill in bed— Isaac Hull Adams was there— Sonnet in Mrs Jaudon’s Album, sent to me by her mother Mrs H. L. White.
30. V:45 Friday

Severe and sudden hemorrhoidal Catarrh— Coll. Jones the adjutant-general, called to bespeak my vote and favour for Spencer Mottram Ball, now a Candidate for a Seat, and heretofore 5 years a member of the Legislature of Virginia.— Mr Hassler was also here and shewed me an inventory of the Journals, maps and Charts of the Survey of the Coast, of which he afterwards sent me a copy.— He invited me again to his Office of Weights and Measures. H.R.U.S. Petitions relating to the duel, were presented by Fairfield, Grennell, Taylor and Hammond of Pennsylvania, and referred to the select Committee— Cambreleng moved to discharge the Committee of the whole on the Union, from the Indian hostility Bill, and reported another with increased appropriations for arrears— A Resolution of call upon the Postmaster General, moved some weeks since, by Arphaxed Loomis, looking to a reduction of the rates of Postage, was now taken up and adopted— Loomis himself is absent. The next Resolution considered was offered by Hopkins, for a select Committee of 5. for investigation retrenchment and reform and to enquire into the expediency of divorcing the Government from the public Press, by prohibiting the employment of Editors of the public Journals, to print official documents— Hopkins made a Speech in support of his Resolution, and Cushman made one against it— No question was taken— Whittlesey called for the orders of the day— Clark enquired of Cambreleng when he proposed to move to go into Committee of the whole, on the Independent Treasury Bill— Cambreleng answered, immediately after the Appropriation Bills shall be disposed of— The remainder of the day was engrossed by Waddy Thomson’s motion to reconsider the Bill for the relief of R. Fulton’s heirs— The main assault upon the Bill was made by Duncan of Ohio— Thomson was magnanimously feeble— Whittlesey, Ogden Hoffman, and Biddle sustained— The Previous question finally arrested the debate—the House refused to reconsider by yeas and nays 81 to 87— Mr Johnson spent the day at Mr Frye’s— Mr. M’Kim of Baltimore is dangerously ill—with a bilious pleurisy— Walk homewards with G. Kemble.
31— III and V. Saturday.

Restless Night—twice up— Morning headache and debility— Unfitted for toil and compulsively idle— Attended nevertheless the House. W. Cost Johnson from the Committee of Accounts made a report concluding with sundry Resolutions respecting the appointment of boys or pages and Messengers for the service of the House— One of the subjects on which sundry abuses have crept into practice.— The consideration of the Report and Resolutions was postponed till Monday next— The boys—Messengers and Postmaster have been hitherto appointed by the Doorkeeper.— Hopkins’s Retrenchment and reform resolution was again taken up, and he replied to Cushman— He was followed by Bond, who introduced sundry Statements of comparative expenditure between the present and former times. The hour expired and Whittlesey called for the orders of the day— The Bill for carrying into effect the 8th. Article of the Florida Treaty, was after considerable discussion, referred to the Committee of private Land-claims— Its object is to give a chance of judicial trial to sundry claimants under doubtful Spanish grants—to lands in West Florida— Sundry private Bills passed without opposition through the Committee of the whole, Legaré in the Chair one case of a pre-emption grant, had nearly slip’d through, when Governor Lincoln was roused against it, followed by Bond, and Lewis Williams, and it was finally passed over, for further consideration— Adjourned between 3 and 4. P.M— Mr Johnson spent the day at Mr Frye’s— My Diary runs in arrears; but I began this Evening an answer to a curious Letter from George Bancroft.

Day.— My failing health encroaches upon my morning hours. I rise from five to six and often later— Write or read till 9—with half an hour of Bible reading with my grand children Mary Louisa and Georgiana Frances— Breakfast— Ride to the House which meets at Noon— They sit till between 4 and 5. P.M— I walk home, and dine— Evening at home with my family— The mail comes with Newspapers and Letters between 9 and 10 at Night, and then I have two hours of as much reading as my decaying eyesight can discover.
